description: From Middle English contenaunce, countenaunce, from Anglo-Norman countenance and Old French contenance, from the present participle of contenir, or from Late Latin continentia, and therefore a doublet of continence.

entries.meaning: Appearance, especially the features and expression of the face.

examples: All feared and obeyed him; to use his roads we must have his countenance.

verbs.description: countenance (third-person singular simple present countenances, present participle countenancing, simple past and past participle countenanced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tolerate, support, sanction, patronise or approve of something.
examples: The cruel punishment was countenanced by the government, although it was not officially legal.
